ARABIC: قَالَتْ يَٰوَيْلَتَىٰٓ ءَأَلِدُ وَأَنَا۠ عَجُوزٌ وَهَٰذَا بَعْلِى شَيْخًا إِنَّ هَٰذَا لَشَىْءٌ عَجِيبٌ

ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: She said, 'Woe is me! How can I give birth when I am an old woman and my husband here is an aged
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: She said: "Woe betide me! Will I give birth when I am old and this my husband be aged? This is indeed surprising!"
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: She said: 'Woe is me! Shall I bear a child now that I am an old woman and my husband is well advanced in years. This is indeed strange!'
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: She said, "Woe is me! How can I have a baby when I am barren and my husband is very old? This is certainly strange".
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: She said, “Oh woe to me – will I bear a child whereas I am an old woman, and this my husband, is an old man? This is something really extraordinary.”
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: She said (in astonishment): "Woe unto me! Shall I bear a child while I am an old woman, and here is my husband an old man Verily, this is a strange thing!"
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: She said: O wonder! shall I bear a son when I am an extremely old woman and this my husband an extremely old man? Most surely this is a wonderful thing.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: She said, 'Woe is me! Shall I bear, being an old woman, and this my husband is an old man? This assuredly is a strange thing.'
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: She said: Oh woe is me! Shall I bear a child when I am an old woman, and this my husband is an old man? Lo! this is a strange thing!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: She said, "Alas! Shall I bear a child in this old age, while my husband here is also old? This is indeed a strange thing!"
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: She said: Oh for me shall bring forth when I am old, and this my husband is advanced in years! Verily a marvellous thing is this!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: She said, ‘Oh, my! Shall I, an old woman, bear [children], and [while] this husband of mine is an old man?! That is indeed an odd thing!’
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: She said: "Alas for me! shall I bear a child, seeing I am an old woman, and my husband here is an old man? That would indeed be a wonderful thing!"
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: She said (in astonishment): "Woe unto me! Shall I bear a child while I am an old woman, and here is my husband, an old man? Verily! This is a strange thing!"
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: She replied: 'Alas for me! Shall I bear (a child) when I am old woman and my husband is advanced in years? This is indeed a strange thing'
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: She said, “Alas for me. Shall I give birth, when I am an old woman, and this, my husband, is an old man? This is truly a strange thing.”
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: She said, "Woe to me! Shall I give birth while I am an old woman and this, my husband, is an old man? Indeed, this is an amazing thing!"
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [11:72] She said, ‘Woe to me! (yā waylatā is an expression used in [reaction to] a serious matter; the alif [suffixed in waylatā] substitutes for the yā’ of the genitive annexation [waylatī, ‘my woe’]). Shall I bear a child when I am an old woman, 99 years old, and this my husband is an old man?, 100 or 120 years old (shaykhan is in the accusative because it is a circumstantial qualifier, operated by the demonstrative import of dhā, ‘this’). Truly this is a strange thing’, that a child should be born to such an aged couple.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (She said: Oh, woe is me! Shall I bear a child when I am an old woman) a 98 year old woman, how can this be? (and this my husband) Abraham (is an old man) 99 years of age? (Lo! This is a strange thing!) this is astonishing!
